list.item: Letter to Tacoma alumnae (Inez Smith Soule Alumnae Club).
Mr. Cresswell & Mrs. Proffit move from Maple Cottage to the Stewart Cottage Boys' dormitory

div1.p: What time do you suppose it is and what are we all doing this Thursday evening? It's 7:45 and all have gone to bed - not only in this house but all over the burg. But when you consider the fact that nearly everyone is up before daylight these early hours are not quite so surprising.

This has been a most strenuous week and fear I may not be very clear and lucid at intervals while composing this epistle! Emily Burton and I spent the weekend in Knoxville - Monday had to make out grades for papers and report cards - Tuesday get off a letter for the Arrow (an awful ment-
al strain) Wednesday prepare for a debate in the evening and today wind up things for our Halloween Party tomorrow night. A Miss Freeman (Iowa Alpha) arrived for short visit today. In between had to have a club meeting with the girls - go to a corn husking and make a call up Baskin's Creek -

So you see if I don't write individually and thank you for your letters - books for Xmas programs - wooden toys etc. it's because of the short days up here. I did so enjoy the letters from Lida, Nellie May, Harrich and Charlotte - and in the course of time shall answer each with appropriate observations.

The principal reason for my not having said anything about baskets is because they are so scarce - The chief basket maker died last summer and others do not take much interest as it's hard work and little pay. Evelyn has so many many orders now that she can't fill - much as she would like to. Perhaps things will work out later on. We have talked about putting it (basket making) into the school but there seem to be about as many reasons for not doing it as for - Miss Langmaid the head of the committee in charge of the school as you no doubt observed in the last Arrow arrives here Saturday for a visit of two months and as her visit has long been anticipated many things have been consequently "hanging five." It does take so long to get things done up here - for the atmosphere is so peaceful - like that the spirit of progress sort of dies out and one grows content with things as they are. For instance one of the chapters sent us dishes months and months ago and they are ambling around somewhere in Tennessee yet for notice came after they had been given up for lost - Meanwhile our cupboard is growing emptier day by day almost - company causes a great planning so
that the meal will suit the scanty supply of dishes - Soup and cereals have to be eaten in cups and tumblers - dinner plates are served three times a day - and every so often you draw a handlesless and saucerless cup - the latter being remedied by an odd small sized plate - the only one of it's kind. Isn't this pathetic sounding? It is too. This house reminds me in so many ways of the frat house in Seattle!

We are all living up here on the hill now for the very day that Mary & Marshall Ogle moved from the little bungalow Mrs. Profit and Mr. Cresswell moved up from the Maples house at the foot of the lane. Ever since
my arrival the domestic troubles of these particular Ogles have been the chief topic of conversation in the burg.
For they involved many people and even the school. It has been very unpleasant at times for us and especially for the two principal actors in the tangle but things all calmed down of a sudden & complete reconciliation followed. Marshall got work at a lumber camp up in the mountains and off they went bag and baggage. He had been very satisfactory on the place till this "other woman" interfered with his home life and Evelyn had to discharge him.

The attendance has been very poor at school this month - molasses
making, digging potates, picking corn and beans seem to be the pricipal reasons. Then too it has been pretty rainy until this week and that has kept some at home. Most of them splash to school barefooted through the mud and real sure enough mud it is! Not even the Fords can get through now to Pigeon Forge - It takes took us two hours to make the seven miles in a buggy down there last week so you can judge of the ruts - chuq holes and depth of mud from that. Several of the girls have stayed here all night rather than go home so far when it is so wet. They like to do it and try to use their napkins knives and forks etc. just right at the table - keeping one eye on us!

Lately all the boys and girls have been playing ring games together at noon and recess and very nicely too. "Farmer in the Dell" is the favorite. They are so funny! I wish you could hear my Lucrettie pour forth excuses for not knowing her history. Today she and one of the others came rushing in just before time for "books" at one - simply dripping with perspiration and demanded that I explain the "census" to them - " O hits so hard Miss Sturley - I can't get nary a thing - not nary a thing!" They are very enthusiastic over the party for tomorrow. The cooking class made doughnuts today and will finish up that part
of it tomorrow. Yesterday noon they all made their jack-o-lanterns - boys and girls together & produced fifteen nice big ones. Then we have made a lot from paper - also black cats - owls - witches and moons which adorn our rooms and the windows for it's to be at the schoolhouse. The girls in the club are going to give a witch song marching around the rooms holding jack-o-lanterns & dressed in sheets and pillow cases. This excitement will be followed by a "track meet" - bobbing for apples and fortune telling.

We have had a spellin' - a "sing" - corn husking and lastly the debate of last night given by the newly organized
Gatlinburg Literary Society - The subject was purely local and good for the community - "Resolved that a public highway is of greater benefit to G. than a railroad." Steve Whaley one of the substantial citizens is president and Mr. Cresswell secretary - So far both boys and girls belong but we rather hope it will work out just for the boys and men.
We are working hard on our Thanksgiving play - "The Courtship of Miles Standish" which will be staged with scenery and costumes complete. We have the spinning wheel at any rate.

Do you know I'm getting quite spoiled for the city ways - We did enjoy our trip
to Knoxville - paning - electric lights - stores etc. looked very good to us - but we were simply delighted with our own green mountains and peaceful burg Sunday night when we made the turn in the road which gives the first glimpse of it all. The foliage is growing quite gorgeous though the bees and butterflies are still with us - and we've been wearing thin clothes all week doors and windows stretched wide open.

If any of you have copies of "Current Events" the "Outlook" "Literary Digest" or similar magazines and papers - we would like to have them for the history classes - in both of which there is need for a certain amount of time for on topics of the day as they never see a newspaper or magazine at home.
Near the close of this letter I discovered a huge blot on the a page of the first part and if you will excuse it am not going to stop and copy but send if as it is - with regret!
With love to each and all of the Inez Smith Soule Alumnae and best wishes for another good meeting next Saturday - the second in the month
